Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2010 06:29PM Lilah wrote: I had two lumpectomies (second time was due to margins not being clear) and it was diagnosed as DCIS after biopsy then IDC after first lumpectomy.  When one margin still was "close" (the rest clear) my ONC suggested I do chemo next and postpone the decision to do either a third lumpectomy or an MX.  I'm glad I had the time to wait and think.  After chemo was done I did a unilateral MX (just the cancer side).  Path showed no more cancer at that point but  I'm glad I did the single MX as I now have peace of mind.  Sometimes I wonder if I should have done bilateral but with all my doctors (PS, BS and ONC) recommending against bilateral it seemed extreme for me to go there so I did not.  If I HAD done it I probably would have more symmetry now but the match isn't bad (I did implant reconstruction) and I'm glad to have feeling in one breast.  Get a second opinion about what to do re: surgery.  I also think you should request a second pathologist's opinion (at another facility) re: the tissue samples you already have.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 07:10AM - edited Jul 13, 2010 07:11AM by Lilah Avoid raw fruits and veggies unless they have a thick skin (so you can eat cantaloupe or watermelon but should avoid apples and peaches, sorry).  I had the same problem during chemo and never craved salads more than when I could not have them.  Cooked veggies are fine.  All fruits and veggies have natural bacteria on their skins that the healthy body easily kills off; when your white blood count is low you are susceptible to these bacteria.  And as Mthomp posted, there is not much you can do to boost your white blood count.
Posts.Title: dietary changes for neutropenia stephanief Lilah

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 07:38AM - edited Jun 29, 2011 07:40AM by Lilah NYruralrider -- after this upcoming lumpectomy they will run tests on the tissue they remove and you will get a full pathology report that will tell you a lot more about the cancer you have.  It may be DCIS, which is non-invasive, though if the lymph nodes are affected it may also be invasive.  I had hormone negative pathology report when I had biopsy but after lumpectomy they found I was HER2+... which meant I had to have chemo and Herceptin.  There are SO many treatments now for breast cancer and, really, it does not have to be a death sentence at all.  It sounds like they have caught yours early, so you absolutely stand a good chance of getting through this.  Sorry your summer got ruined -- that sucks -- but here's hoping for a good year (and years) to come! Once you've had this surgery you should consult with an Oncologist and a Radiologist to find out your treatment options.  Lumpectomy is often treated with radiation, for example, and that is something to discuss with these two types of doctors.  It can't hurt to make appointments now as a follow up after surgery (and recovery from surgery).

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 06:37AM Lilah wrote: Oh I do know one thing re Her2+ (which is what I was) -- I was told that when you are Her2+ the best treatment is Herceptin.  Studies have shown that Herceptin works BEST when given with chemo.  Standard treatment is ACTH (Adriamyacin, Carboplatin, Taxol and Herceptin); more recently some studies have suggested that TCH (no Adriamyacin) is equally as helpful.  You take the chemo for a shorter period... the Herceptin for a year (most do it every three weeks).  The Herceptin is a drug (not chemo) and though it has risk and some minor SEs is easily tolerated and not at all like chemo.  HER2 cancer is more highly metastatic than other types of breast cancer but thanks to the invention of Herceptin, which wraps itself around HER2 cells and stops them from growing, it is no longer as powerful or frightening a diagnosis (as I understand it).

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 08:43PM - edited Oct 1, 2009 08:49PM by Lilah Well since my last post I did meet with my BS and she basically laid it out for me like this: 8-15% chance of recurrence of BC if I do lumpectomy/radiation... 1-3% if I do a unilateral MX.  She added that she thought I was more in the 15% area if I opt for lump/rad and said if I came back in the future with a recurrence following a lumpectomy/radiation she "wouldn't be surprised" due to the size of my tumor (which though not a LUMP did spread along two areas of milk ducts)... I am also going to opt for the unilateral MX (although if my BRCA test is positive I'll do the bilateral -- that said, I will be surprised if it is because no one in my family has had BC or cancer of any kind for that matter).  Glad to hear you don't regret your decision patsfan!  It is so reassuring.  I too will opt for an implant and agree it would be nice if there were a perfect option.  For me, an implant seems to have the least amount of risk (and the least recovery), which at this point is most appealing to me. Cheers, Lilah
Posts.Title: Surgery Again or what? cabmom Lilah

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 09:05AM Lilah wrote: I think it depends on (1) whether the doctors feel the prognosis for lumpectomy plus radiation is the same as for mastectomy and (2) whether how it looks is important to you.  As I understand it, a third lumpectomy (assuming it does get that final clear/clean margin) will mean the need for plastic surgery, but the end cosmetic result will likely not be perfect.  With mastectomy you will get, ultimately, a more perfectly shaped breast albeit one that is either an implant or the result of other surgery (such as TRAMM)... but which also will have a scar.  If you don't feel comfortable that lumpectomy/radiation will kill the cancer, many feel safer with mastectomy.  Ultimately, it's down to (1) what is going to most reduce your risk of cancer returning and (2) what is important to you cosmetically.  At the moment, I am in a similar situation in that I had two lumpectomies and, following the second had clean/clear margins in all but one spot, which was "close" -- so I need to go back.  My Onc chose to have my do chemo first and final surgery later and tells me that the prognosis for me is the same whether I do lumpectomy/radiation or just a mastectomy.  I'm waiting for results of BRACA test (though I don't expect to have the gene as no one in my family has had cancer -- still, you never know and I did have one factor that made it worth checking).  If my BRACA test comes back positive I'm have a bilateral prophylactic mastectomy.  If not, I hope to go the lump/rad mainly because I would rather FEEL my breast and have it be imperfect than not feel it (the result of any reconstruction following mastectomy, as I understand it).  I don't think anyone can make this decision for you.  My advice is to listen carefully when they talk about what is the safest/best bet for fighting the cancer and doing all you can to assure it won't return. Cheers, Lilah
Posts.Title: Surgery Again or what? cabmom Lilah

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:59PM Lilah wrote: Definitely get another opinion from a different PS.  I agree with the others: you aren't too fat to get TEs and begin the process for implant reconstruction (if that is what you want).... you could get the TEs and start losing weight (if you want to)... it takes some months to undergo that process anyway.  And if you want autologous reconstruction (DIEP or one of the GAP surgeries) then be sure you are speaking to someone who specializes in that particular surgery.  Further: make sure the PS (or PS's -- because you can get as many opinions as you want!) are specialists in RECONSTRUCTION and NOT augmentation. Sending hugs!  And strength!

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 01:04PM - edited May 16, 2010 01:05PM by Lilah Cincan -- I'm way past the shadow.  I finished chemo October 9 and the 5 o'clock shadow started in early January (right around New Year's).  I now have about an inch of very straight, straggly hair (which I had cut 2 weeks ago to it's current one inch length).  It looks "almost intentional" right now, as a friend recently informed me :)  I lost all of my eyebrows and lashes from mid-November til end of December but noticed at end of December that the brows were coming back and they did grow back quickly, as did the lashes.  I think more recently the brows and lashes have thinned a bit but there are plenty of them there and I think the thinning is just the hair growth pattern getting back to a more normal stagger schedule.  As I understand it, eyebrows and lashes usually grow and fall out quickly but in a staggered fashion so that you never see the loss and chemo disrupts the staggered pattern... so that is why some see more than one cycle of loss and regrowth.

Mary -- my eyebrows hung in there throughout chemo but really starting falling out about 3 weeks PFC (around Thanksgiving) and were totally gone just before Christmas; but by New Year's I had visible brows again (so they seemed to grow back pretty quickly).  Judy -- wtg on the hair!  You look great. Re: eyebrow pencils and powder.. I just went to target and bought a few that had pencil on one end/brush on the other... I'm betting that if you got to Macy's or Bloomingdale's or Nordstrom's or any big department store with a bank of cosmetic counters you can get someone to sell you some powdered eyebrow material and brush (or whatever) as well as show you how to use it.  My advice though is that your brows will grow in pretty fast and an inexpensive pencil/brush combo will probably do for the few weeks they are truly gone (as opposed to in-between). Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 11:56AM Lilah wrote: Juannelle -- your grandson sounds adorable!  And he is right.  Because they had told me at first that I could have just a lumpectomy (then decided later that an MX was much safer in my case), I had a really hard time adjusting (well maybe there is no easy time of it when it comes to that news).  I also had two lumpectomies, then chemo, then uni MX... so had time to think about it.  Anyway, one day while grieving over it my boyfriend said something similar: "It's not like you're losing an arm" -- and he was right (as is your grandson) -- it's horrible to lose one's hair and to lose a boob... but arms and legs would be worse.  At this point I am grateful to be alive, to be (for the moment) cancer-free, and to be on the mend (with all the hard emotional stuff behind me, hopefully). Sherri -- I mostly lost my eyebrows and lashes AFTER I finished chemo.  I finished on November 9.  By Thanksgiving my eyebrows were sparse.  By Christmas I had NO eyebrows or lashes BUT by New Year's I had them back.  The day after Christmas I realized I had five o'clock shadow where my eyebrows had been and the hair had come in visibly by New Year's (probably thickened up a bit a few weeks after that but what I had by New Year's was good enough)!  So the answer is: they come back fast. Jancie -- as far as I can tell the eyelashes are even.  I don't bother much with makeup either.  Since I started chemo August 1 I wore it exactly once -- at Thanksgiving  -- because my mom asked me to put some make up on so I would look bad LOL.  Mothers are so pure, aren't they?  She was right.  I did look better/healthier with it on!  Lilah

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 01:02PM Lilah wrote: Cincan -- I'm way past the shadow.  I finished chemo October 9 and the 5 o'clock shadow started in early January (right around New Year's).  I now have about an inch of very straight, straggly hair (which I had cut 2 weeks ago to it's current one inch length).  It looks "almost intentional" right now, as a friend recent informed me :)  I lost all of my eyebrows and lashes from mid-November til end of December but noticed at end of December that the brows were coming back and they did grow back quickly, as did the lashes.  I think more recently the brows and lashes have thinned a bit but there are plenty of them there and I think the thinning is just the hair growth getting back to a more normal stagger schedule.  As I understand it, eyebrows and lashes usually grow and fall out quickly but in a staggered fashion so that you never see the loss and chemo disrupts the staggered pattern... so that is why some see more than one cycle of loss and regrowth.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 12:32PM - edited Feb 28, 2010 12:33PM by Lilah Bugsfire -- because she will get chemo and Herceptin, your mom's prognosis is excellent.  As I understand it Herceptin (which works better when given with chemo) is a miracle drug for us HER2+ women.  Every pathology is different, but I was told that my chance of recurrence would be less than 10% after all treatment (which is better than a healthy woman's chance of getting BC at all at 12.5% so I will take it).  There are some who say that after 5 years of no disease the percentages are even lower.  You and your mom just need to focus on getting through the treatment (I worked all through chemo but it did get challenging toward the end of the three months).  Herceptin, which I'm still on, is a breeze (no SEs for me). Warrior -- re: getting started with public speaking... do you know what you'd speak about?  If you can draw up a plan for a public speech topic (I assume related to BC) you could contact your local cancer center or hospital or breast center and see if they are interested.  My local breast center, which is also where my onc is and where I get chemo, runs all sorts of seminars and I can imagine that a BC survivor speaking on the things you need to know (for example) might interest them.  Sometimes with public speaking, it seems to me, it's a matter of starting and then word of mouth takes over. LookingForward -- 13% isn't bad when you consider that 12.5% is what anyone's chance is (prior to ever having BC).   I DO think though that your chance of recurrence with BC IS less after 5 years... that's what I am told anyway.  But that MAY be specific to my pathology and the HER2+ and Herceptin. Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 12:01PM Lilah wrote: I asked my BS why some women only have a few and others many lymph nodes removed and my BS explained it like this: when they do the SNB one node lights up... the sentinel or FIRST node that is reached by the fluids coming out of your breast.  If it shows the presence of cancer in a prelimary test (which is done while you are under in most cases) they remove all remaining nodes around the one that lit up.  It's a small cluster of lymphatic tissue (and as far as I understand it individual nodes are not discernible to the naked eye, just the area of lymph tissue).  So it is what it is -- there is a cluster of nodes there and some women only have a few... others have many.  They remove the whole cluster.  Later the lab examines the tissue, counts the nodes, looks for cancer in each one.  So that is why there is a difference.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 11:51AM Lilah wrote: Jag -- the Her2 test is key.  If you are Her2 positive you need Herceptin and if you need Herceptin you need chemo as studies show that Herceptin works better in concert with the chemo.  Cookiegal is right, though, that you need an oncotype test to be conducted (if you are Her2 positive, Oncotype does not matter -- in fact it is not used because of the fact that you MUST have chemo if Her2 positive).  Your oncologist will give you info, I am sure; ask him/her if an oncotype has been done and, if not, request one.  A low score means that chemo would not significantly lower your chance of recurrence, basically. I know -- for me -- seeing my Onc was the most helpful step in the process (surgeons don't really tell you much except about cutting you :)  If you do have to do chemo, don't worry.  There are great drugs now to help with SEs and the worst thing that happens is you lose your hair, which grows back.  I too found the thought of chemo terrifying but now that I've been through it I have to say the terror OF it was far worse than the chemo itself.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 04:44PM Lilah wrote: I too am scheduled for a Right MX (Dec 9) and agonized over whether to take both and also what sort of reconstruction.  In the end, with my doctors telling me there was no reason to take the healthy breast too, I am opting for unilateral.  My PS says she will do her best to get symmetry (and certainly the pictures she showed me looked really great) and generally give me a good breast replacement.  I had two lumpectomies and still one margin close (three other were clear) but also had multifocal DCIS and IDC and was told that another lumpectomy (with rads) would still leave me at a greater risk (15%) for a reoccurence of the cancer vs. mastectomy (1 - 3% chance).  Healthy breast risk of reoccurrence is small (less than .5%) though over time the percentage increases; in spite of that, the doctors say no need to remove and quite frankly I don't want to remove my healthy breast.  I will have a reduction/lift at exchange, to attempt better symmetry (I have large DD breasts and expect the implant on the right to be smaller than that, so the remaining, healthy breast will need to be reduced... which is fine with me!) Anyway I think you are already having your surgery (or have had it) so I am writing really to say: I am another one like you.  More women, I think, get bilateral than unilateral.  I worried for a few weeks about whether I would have a satisfying symmetry with unilateral, but the truth is you can have symmetry issues with bilateral, too.  Bottom line is: find a PS who you trust and who listens to you.  And remember that nature rarely creates perfect symmetry :)  God knows my original breasts have never been terribly symmetrical.  Cheers, Lilah

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 02:55PM Lilah wrote: Julie - welcome to the forum and how wonderful of you to be going through this with your mom.  I assume the diagnosis on your sig is your Mom's diagnosis.  Chemo is different for everyone.  Some have very few side effects, others more.  What is the chemo your mom is going to be received every three weeks starting on Friday?  (Which specific one?)  Different chemos have different side effects. I had Adriamiacin and Cytoxin x 4 (dose dense) every two weeks followed by Taxol x 4 (dose dense) every two weeks and Herceptin (which is not chemo) every three weeks starting with the Taxol.  I am still on the Herceptin every three weeks til next September.  Your mom is HER2- so she is not going to be getting Herceptin. The A/C made my hair fall out (everywhere) starting with the second treatment.  I was given steroids, anti-nausea drugs (Emend) and Neulasta (to help with white blood count) throughout and as a result had no nausea.  The steroids always kept me up all night that first night after a dose.  I did end up having a fever a few weeks into the A/C and was hospitalized to receive intravenous antibiotics (I had lunch at a salad bar -- d'oh! -- not a wise move when your immunity is weakened).  With Taxol I continued receiving steroids (sleepless the first night) and Neulasta; they also gave me Benadryl and something else to help with potential allergic reaction (I had none).  My main problem with Taxol was neuropathy.  Pain in legs and feet.  It went away after I was done. Hope this helps! Lilah

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 10:14PM - edited Mar 11, 2010 10:17PM by Lilah Sara - I had AC dose dense x 4 followed by Taxol dose dense x 4 (both every 2 weeks) plus started Herceptin once every three weeks with the Taxol.  I worked all through the chemo, though to be fair I only had to show up somewhere once a week on Thursdays (by and large).  I had my chemo on Mondays and was fine by Thursday (except maybe toward the end of the Taxol, by which time I did have a couple of rough weeks).  It definitely helped that I could take it easy at the front end but had a reason to rise above/be normal as possible toward the end of each chemo week (I teach at a university and Thursday is my teaching day).  They have amazing meds now for the SEs.  My only bad SE really (aside from hair loss) was that I too developed a fever which caused them to put me in the hospital for a few nights to get IV antibiotics (I personally thought that was overkill as I felt fine almost immediately upon being admitted).  I went to a salad bar the weekend after my second AC -- BIG mistake -- and they think I got food poisoning (which caused the fever).  They had not told me that raw fruits and veggies have bacteria that healthy immune systems fight off easily but chemo-impaired immune systems do NOT.  So be careful with public restaurants and the eating of raw fruits and veggies while on the AC. I definitely agree with Gina -- counting down the weeks was a big help in getting through it all.  Lilah

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2010 04:14PM Lilah wrote: Oh I have I had surgery!  When I was first diagnosed last spring I had two lumpectomies in June ... the second one having gotten ALMOST perfect margins (three clear, one close)... then I did chemo from August to October... then had a unilateral MX (right breast) in December.  I am in the TE phase now and will have an exchange (and a lift/reduction of my left breast) in May.  So yeah I've had surgery :) The first lumpectomy (my first surgery since I was 16 years old) I was very scared.  I was mostly afraid of the anesthesia.  But then the day of surgery I have to say the best part was being put to sleep and waking up and it being over.  The second surgery I was relaxed because the first was so easy (they removed so little, it seemed to me, that you could hardly tell anything was gone).  The second surgery sucked.  I had the SNB and they removed a lot of tissue from my breast (making it look awful).  The area where they removed nodes hurt and was numb for a long time and my shoulder was stiff for months (though eventually I got info about stretches and that helped).  So by the time my third surgery rolled around I was apprehensive about post-surgical pain (though no longer worried about anesthesia).  Amazingly, my MX was a breeze.  When I woke up in the recovery room I felt a flood of relief because I knew immediately that the pain was not going to be bad (when I woke up after the second lumpectomy I was in BAD pain).  All in all, it's been very good since then and the growing TE is sort of fun.  I am looking forward to my (hopefully) final surgery in May and the implant, which everyone says will be MUCH softer than this horribly hard TE.  What kind of surgery are you having Mouse?

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2010 03:03PM - edited Apr 26, 2010 03:04PM by Lilah Reread Lauren's sig, Sgilbert... she FINISHED chemo five months after diagnosis.  Looks like she had surgery a month after diagnosis and started chemo two months after that (which is pretty common).  I had originally been diagnosed with DCIS and had surgery 3 weeks after diagnosis (and then a second excision two weeks after that)... then did chemo... then a Uni MX (chemo started about two months after diagnosis as well).  I had the MX after because my ONC wanted me to start chemo already!  Also, it wasn't til I had surgery that they knew I needed chemo (due to HER2 positive status, which was not detectable from the biopsy).  The MX was recommended because after two excisions I still had one close margin (as it turned out, though, my breast tissue was clear of all cancer... ah well... at least I didn't have to have rads).

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 11:03AM Lilah wrote: Designer Mom -- if you had Oncotype testing that means you were ER+ and/or PR+... and they do the test to determine whether you would benefit from chemo (or whether the damage it does would outweigh the healing).  Often with ER/PR positive cancers they treat with a pill form of chemo (which does not do as much damage) plus radiation.  Grade of the cancer is also a factor in whether Chemo is strongly effective (I believe I've read that a Grade 3 cancer -- which is an aggressive cancer -- is more responsive to chemo than a grade 1).  Do you know if you are HER2+?  That would also be a factor in whether or not you get chemo.  If you DO end up having chemo, that comes before the radiation.  Most women it's surgery (whether lumpectomy or mastectomy), then chemo, then radiation (if you have all three).  I had two lumpectomies...then chemo... then a unilateral MX (because there was still one margin that wasn't clear after second lumpectomy... but my ONC wanted me to start chemo after the second lumpectomy because she felt I had waited long enough... surgery delays the start of chemo).  I did not have radiation because I had the MX and there was no cancer left in the breast when they tested it after removal.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 12:10AM - edited Jul 22, 2011 12:11AM by Lilah It is always wise to get multiple opinions.  And make sure that the doctors whose opinions you are getting on this are Oncologists and not Breast Surgeons.  If positive for all receptors that means one of those receptors is HER2 -- HER2 positive cancer, except perhaps in very early stages, is always treated with Herceptin for the best chance of preventing recurrence; and Herceptin works best with Chemo.  If your Mom is HER2 positive then you absolutely should talk to another Oncologist (or AN Oncologist if this doctor is a surgeon)... she really does need chemo AND herceptin.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 09:59PM Lilah wrote: Cool Breeze -- It's such a horrible roller coaster and we learn as we go and all we want to do is get it out so I feel for you.  Doing chemo first (I had two lumpectomies and didn't know until just before the second one that I was HER-2+) is a good way to go, from what I've read, especially with HER-2+... my surgeries were in June.  My diagnosis in May (my first suspicious mammo was at end of March, biopsy in April).  At first everyone said it was nothing and no rush.  Had my first lumpectomy June 2... second June 23.  Met my oncologist on July 17, who sent me to a new surgeon and PS (because my old surgeon worked with a PS who was not in my plan).  Navigating the insurance and jumping the hurdles of new info was hair-raising.  In spite of it all, once they told me in early May that I had cancer I actually acted FAST and it still took that long.  I started chemo August 3 and will have a unilateral right MX in December (a month after chemo ends, which is required wait time).  My two lumpectomies got me clean margins in all but one spot, which was a close margin; my new BS told me my chances of a recurrence were much less with MX, so that is why I am doing that.  So far, all doctors feel there is no need for a bilateral MX so that's where I'm staying.  I guess I'm telling you all of this because it's not easy navigating and even when you are running as fast as you can there is the waiting for scheduling and all the things that have nothing to do with curing you.  Push for answers.  Read and educate yourself as best you can.  In my case, my oncologist just wanted me to have treatment for my cancer and stop having to wait around for surgeons and insurance.  I am glad I did chemo first (will have my last tx on Nov 9) because I feel I'm dealing with the cancer head on and getting to Herceptin sooner (which has become the standard of treatment along with chemo) to treat the HER-2.  But if you have a chance to get your surgery soon, then do that.  Either way works and both ways can and will treat your cancer.  Cheers, Lilah
